title: Trust & Vulnerability
description: Explore how you build trust and share your true selves.

questions.text: What helps me trust you most?
choices: Consistency in your words and actions
Being honest even when it's hard
Keeping my secrets safe
Following through on commitments

therapeutic.rationale: Trust is built through different currencies for different people. Consistency builds trust through predictability; honesty builds trust through truth; confidentiality builds trust through safety; follow-through builds trust through reliability. Understanding how your partner builds trust helps you invest in the right behaviors.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust currencies mean you're each reassured by different behaviors. The consistency-seeker needs predictability; the honesty-seeker needs truth even when uncomfortable. Know what builds trust for your partner and deliver it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust currencies mean you'll naturally build security through the same behaviors. You understand what builds trust because it's what builds trust for you too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What behavior from your partner most strengthens your trust? What has your partner done that significantly built trust? What would erode it?

questions.text: What makes me feel safe being vulnerable with you?
choices: Knowing you won't judge me
How gently you respond to my feelings
Your confidentiality with what I share
That you've been vulnerable with me too

therapeutic.rationale: Vulnerability requires specific conditions to feel safe. Non-judgment allows raw honesty; gentle responses protect tender feelings; confidentiality ensures privacy; mutual vulnerability creates equality. Creating the conditions for your partner's vulnerability is essential for deep intimacy.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different vulnerability conditions mean you each need different safety guarantees. The non-judgment seeker needs to feel unshamed; the mutual-vulnerability seeker needs reciprocity. Create the conditions your partner needs to open up.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vulnerability conditions mean you'll naturally create safety for each other. You understand what makes vulnerability possible because you need the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel safe being vulnerable? When has your partner created perfect conditions for you to open up? What would help you share more deeply?

questions.text: What's hardest for me to share with you?
choices: Fears and insecurities
Past mistakes or regrets
Needs I think might burden you
Doubts or worries about us

therapeutic.rationale: What we struggle to share reveals our deepest vulnerabilities. Fear-sharers protect their fragility; regret-sharers protect their self-image; need-sharers fear being too much; relationship-doubt sharers fear destabilizing. Knowing your partner's hardest topics helps you receive them with extra care.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different hard topics reveal different protected areas. When your partner shares something difficult for them, respond with awareness that this took courage in their specific way.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared difficulty areas suggest you both protect similar parts of yourselves. You understand the courage it takes because you struggle with the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's hardest for you to tell your partner? What would need to change for you to share it? What would you need from them if you did?

questions.text: How do I know when you're being completely honest with me?
choices: You make eye contact and seem present
Your words and body language match
You share even unflattering truths
I can just feel it—I know you

therapeutic.rationale: We each have signals that indicate authenticity to us. Eye contact signals presence and courage; congruence signals alignment; unflattering truths signal commitment to honesty; intuition signals deep knowing. Understanding what signals honesty for your partner helps you communicate genuinely in ways they can trust.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different honesty signals mean different things read as 'truthful' to each of you. The eye-contact seeker may doubt avoidant truth-telling; the intuition-trusting person may not need external signals. Show honesty in your partner's signal language.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared honesty signals mean you'll read authenticity the same way. You'll trust each other's truth through the same cues.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you know when your partner is being completely honest? What signals do you look for? When do you doubt their authenticity—and are you right?

questions.text: What would make me trust you even more?
choices: More consistency day to day
Sharing your inner world more openly
Being more reliable with commitments
Being more present in difficult moments

therapeutic.rationale: Trust has levels—even strong relationships can deepen further. More consistency provides greater predictability; more sharing creates deeper knowing; more reliability builds stronger foundation; difficult-moment presence proves commitment. Knowing what would deepen trust for your partner gives you a roadmap for strengthening the relationship.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust-deepening paths reveal different growth edges. Your partner is telling you what would make them feel even more secure. This is valuable information for strengthening your bond.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust-deepening desires mean you want to grow security in the same direction. Work together on what would make you both feel more trusting.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make you trust your partner even more than you do now? Have you told them? What's preventing you from asking for it?
